topics.body:
"@Grieffon":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538982b86368721bde0c0600#post_538982b86368721bde0c0600
[bq="Grieffon"]Anyone miss 2d animated movies?

The last one I can remember is The Princess and the Frog, which wss... 5 years ago.

Are kids' taste really so bad they can't go to a movie theater without everything being 3d?[/bq]
It's about costs really.  Traditional animation is expensive to the point you're starting to see cgi in even cartoons and anime now to cut down costs.  A lot of times it's easy to notice, but if done well it can be hard to notice.  The reason why cgi is so often easy to notice in traditional 2d animation is 95% of the time the person they get to do it is a fresh rookie out of college and most audiences have seen cgi so much they have learned how to immediately pick it out.

Personally that's why I like RWBY's art style, cause they realized "Blending in cgi with traditional animation is really hard to do. . eh fuck it we'll just make it cgi and stylize it as anime".  It's probably why there's so many cgi only movies cause your average audience member can immediately pick out what's cgi when it's used in live action movies or animated movies.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body: Why do people treat CGI like it's a bad thing? Animation of any kind is a tool. A tool used to tell a story. I don't care what art style you use as long as the story is good.

topics.body:
"@SquiggyBomb":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5389f62f63687222e6520300#post_5389f62f63687222e6520300
Eh; I'm kind of on the fence when it comes to cgi; on the one hand I like what can be done with it and on the other I know there's a overwhelming probability that it's going to be done extremely poorly the majority of the time.

Speaking of cgi here's a side by side comparison of what foodfight was supposed to look like:
http://pedants-r-us.tumblr.com/post/87231201285/foodfight-animation-before-and-after-the-tape
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@SquiggyBomb":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5389f62f63687222e6520300#post_5389f62f63687222e6520300

It's basically because of the illusion. When you watch a movie your suspension of disbelief makes you feel you're in there. It's like immersion in a videogame.

CGI as opposed to hand drawn animation, gives the illusion that what's on the screen is a close to reality as you can possibly get.

topics.author: 4fde5cee945b700a970060fc

topics.body:
"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538a2ece6368721d2dc50000#post_538a2ece6368721d2dc50000
A machine doesn't drink-and-drive, or talk on the phone. It also doesn't pass the red light, or pass speed limit, and makes far less errors than humans. To be honest, a self-driving car is much more trustworthy than a car operated by humans.

With that said, why would they give the car no steering wheel and no brake? People need time to warm up to the idea, and that will just scare them away. Not to mention that in the beginning, there might be errors, so it's better to have some emergency manual control than not.
topics.author: 4fded3ad945b700aaa01381d

topics.body:
Automated Cars. That makes me uncomfortable. I'm sorry, but I prefer a human being I can talk to, not a bunch of circuitry with no emotion.

It's probably more efficient...but it just rubs me the wrong way.
